entrydata.text: Explore the history of this fascinating science, from the famous hoax of Piltdown Man, to the superstitions surrounding Central America’s Crystal Skulls. This course deals with topics surrounding the history of Archaeology, its historical and contemporary ties with religious and political institutions, and the commodification of cultural property.
Bloor Street West and Queen's Park

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Explore Mesopotamia: Old Excavations and New Tricks - Rediscovering the Royal Cemetery of Ur

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
History

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Old Excavations and New Tricks will focus on the attendants buried with Ur’s kings and queens, re-examining Charles Leonard Woolley’s assumption that they had gone willingly to their deaths, by drinking some deadly or soporific drug. Recent forensic analysis of the skulls of two royal attendants in the University of Pennsylvania Museum has provided compelling evidence that they had been killed by a blow to the head. It also turned up some limited evidence for the post-mortem treatment of the corpses.
Bloor Street West and Queens Park

textlist.text: Jenenne Whitfield, Executive Director will present a detailed picture of The Heidelberg Project which is an open-air art environment in the heart of an urban community on Detroit’s East Side. Tyree Guyton, founder and artistic director, uses everyday, discarded objects to create a two block area full of color, symbolism, and intrigue. Now in its 27th year, the Heidelberg Project is recognized around the world as a demonstration of the power of creativity to transform lives.
A Q&A moderated by author and Senior Editor/Co-Owner Spacing Magazine will follow the presentation.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Who's In Bed With The Butler

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: A California billionaire has bequeathed all of his assets to his only daughter Constance – except the 22-million-dollar yacht he wanted Josephine to have, a 25 million-dollar art collection left to Rene and some priceless antique automobiles willed to Marjorie. The butler seems to hold the key and she learns from him that the three sultry ladies were her father’s lovers. Could the butler be behind the shenanigans – and is he carrying on with all of the ladies in question? Does the elderly, deaf housekeeper really have a pet rat? Can the bumbling detective hired by Constance really be so inept, linguistically as well as professionally? And why has the butler hired an actress to play his wife?
Kipling Avenue and Lake Shore Boulevard West

The "10 most" is the only national program within the Hispanic community in Canada with 60 winners in six provinces. The program, which has been personally recognized by Prime Minister Stephen Harper, has had a presence in Vancouver, Montreal, Ottawa, Toronto and Saskatchewan.

Judges for the awards include past winners as well as executives and journalists from the Globe & Mail, National Post, Toronto Star, CBC, Toronto 2015 Pan American Games, Greater Toronto Marketing Alliance, Canadian Council for the Americas, Canadian Aboriginal & Minority Supplier Council, Diversity Business Network and the University of Ottawa.
The keynotes will be announced at www.HispanicBusiness.ca

entrydata.text: The 2013 Toronto Science Festival is a weekend-long celebration of science, Sept. 27 - 29, that explores the theme of Life in the Universe through keynote talks, panels, film screenings, live dance and music performances, a Cafe Scientifique Brunch-with-a-Scientist, microscope and telescope observing sessions, and more. Guests incl. Cdn astronaut Julie Payette, Mars Rover scientist Jim Bell, evolutionary biologist Sean Carroll, SETI pioneer Jill Tarter and many more. Plus, TSF will be sending a message submitted by the public into space in an attempt to communicate with extraterrestrial beings. The festival is organized by the University of Toronto.

entrydata.name: Image
entrydata.text: http://wx.toronto.ca/festevents.nsf/all/B811082DF4E7F89385257BD5006C05A2/$File/9-11 national security state - presentation Sept-28-2013 U Toronto.jpg

textlist.text: Terrorism has served as the foundation of the global war on terror, warrantless surveillance by intelligence agencies and the loss of civil liberties. Professors Graeme MacQueen (former founding Director of McMaster University's Peace Studies Centre) and Michael Keefer (formerly Professor at the University of Guelph and President of the ACCUTE) will investigate 9/11, the anthrax attacks, the rise of the national security state, and the implications of these events on our future.
Event organized by: Adnan Zuberi Director and Producer of Award Winning Documentary, "9/11 in the Academic Community" & Barrie Zwicker Political Activist & Former Journalist at The Globe and Mail

textlist.text: Live performances

Studio BLR makes theatre accessible to a live music community and theatre goers alike by turning Stanley's "Poker Game" into a band practice and showcasing a different local live band in each performance. Don't miss this modern retelling of Tennessee Williams' classic tragedy, A Streetcar Named Desire - The House Show! Yes that's right A Streetcar Named Desire will be staged in a house! The house where Stanley and Stella live!

They are a punk rock couple, playing host to Stella's visiting sister Blanche, who cannot adjust to the clashing lifestyles between her own, and her sister's "brute" of a husband,and his rock band "This Party of Apes".

textlist.text: The IFOA pays tribute to Alice Munro, a Canadian literary icon. After a celebrated career as one of Canada’s most beloved, internationally recognized and award-winning authors, Alice Munro announced her retirement in June 2013. This fall, IFOA will host a "who's-who" of Canada's literary community, including other writers, close colleagues and family members, as they present readings of Munro's work.
This event will be hosted by Douglas Gibson, Alice Munro’s editor for almost 40 years.

Chinese artist Ai Weiwei is one of the most prolific, provocative and significant artists at work today. The AGO becomes the only Canadian stop on a North American tour that is already drawing crowds — and controversy — at the Smithsonian’s Hirshhorn Museum in Washington, D.C.

Featuring photographs, sculpture, installation art and audio and video pieces, Ai Weiwei: According to What? examines how the artist spotlights the complexities of a changing world and probes such issues as freedom of expression, individual and human rights, the power of digital communication and the range of creative practice that characterizes contemporary art today both in China and globally.
Organized by Mori Art Museum, Tokyo, and the Art Gallery of Ontario

entrydata.text: Canadian Journalists for Free Expression and the Art Gallery of Ontario

textlist.text: The Art Gallery of Ontario (AGO) joins forces with Canadian Journalists for Free Expression (CJFE) to present a multi-media event honouring dissident artist Ai Weiwei and paying tribute to his relentless pursuit of free expression through art, social media and political protest.

Hosted by Anna Maria Tremonti, of CBC-Radio’s The Current, the evening will feature a lineup of prominent Canadian writers, poets, musicians, visual artists and performers, demonstrating with words, music and imagery the vital role creativity plays as a catalyst for social change and individual freedom.

Over 90 cents of every dollar raised at AIDSbeat goes to support the Canadian Foundation for AIDS Research.

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: An Te Liu MONO NO MA is the second artist intervention commissioned by the Gardiner Museum. Talented conceptual artist An Te Liu adopts his own interpretation from the Museum and has drawn inspiration for his 19 slip-cast site-specific sculptures from artefacts found in the Gardiner’s Ancient Americas collection and the contemporary consumer milieu. With MONO NO MA, acclaimed An Te Liu explores the spaces around things.

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: The Swansea Senior's Multi Media Art Class have been meeting for the last 20 years or so every Tuesday morning at the Swansea Town Hall to draw, sketch and create. Every year we like to display all our creative work from the previous year. We work in a variety of mediums from acrylic to watercolour. From September 27th to November 5th we will be showcasing our work in the 2nd Floor Lobby. Drop by to see our creations any time during opening hours of the Town Hall. If you are interested in joining us weekly, drop by any Tuesday morning!

entrydata.text: Art Toronto is Canada's only modern and contemporary fine art Fair, providing unique access to the Canadian art market without dilution from competing satellite fairs. It serves as the galvanizing vehicle for the nation's art world. Considered the country's must-attend event for art collectors and industry professionals, Art Toronto is the place for galleries wishing to attract a new sophisticated market of collectors, and professionals, and the place to network with a diverse and well connected group of fellow participants. Building on its successful platform as an exceptionally well serviced, user friendly Fair, Art Toronto presents more than 100 select galleries, complemented with special projects, exhibits and dynamic cultural programs.
Front Street West and John Street

entrydata.text: TD Bank Group Presents the 20th Annual Art with Heart, a benefit for Casey House. Canada's leading auction of contemporary Canadian art features an exciting curated collection of emerging & established artists raises funds for Casey House, Toronto's HIV/AIDS hospital. This year’s 86-lot collection features work by some of the most esteemed contemporary artists working in Canada today, including works by Edward Burtynsky, Angela Leach, James Lahey, David Urban, John Scott, Tim Pitsiulak, Toni Hafkenscheid, Paul Butler, Joshua Jensen-Nagle and Diana Thorneycroft. Ticket price includes open bar and food.

textlist.text: ARTSIDEOUT (ASO) is UTSC's largest, one-day multi-disciplinary festival that celebrates both art and culture in physical and conceptual spaces.

ASO involves the widest range of students and community projects; and offers variety in showcasing site-specific art installations, exhibitions, performances, concerts, musical acts, and film screenings. ASO 2013, upon entering its sixth annual year, emphasizes interactivity and innovative perceptual experiences across all art forms.

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: The Power Plant Contemporary Art Gallery

textlist.text: In this bilingual lecture conducted in French and English, curator Ami Barak will discuss his contribution to Toronto’s Scotiabank Nuit Blanche and compare his experience here with his earlier work on the Parisian iteration. Describing Nuit Blanche as the city turned into a one-night, open-air museum, Barak will reflect on the process of taking manufactured objects back to the streets and reconciling the public with the ubiquitous status of the artwork.
Read more online at our website.

entrydata.text: The BrainSTEM: Your Future is Now Festival will connect remarkable technological innovations to the scientific breakthroughs that make them possible. The festival will feature highly interactive science-centre style exhibits, special presentations, public lectures, Science in the Club events and insider-tours of the world-class facilities of Perimeter Institute. Showcasing cutting edge technology and innovation, Your Future is Now Festival exhibits will deeply engage attendees, inspiring them with the wonders of science, technology and the fundamentals of physics, engineering and mathematics that make this progress possible. Live Webcast Public Lectures features: James Grime, Ray Laflamme and Lucy Hawking.

Theatre

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Nana has been in a coma for fifteen months. She is in a vegetative state. The doctors say she won’t wake up from her deep sleep. In the high brow Lagos hospital room, Nana’s daughter is ready to pull the plug. Her son, an immigrant in North America, is rushing back to stop his sister. It is a battle of wills. But they are not alone, or are they? Trapped in the dark void of her coma, Nana can still hear voices. She hears the bitter arguments that erupt between the siblings—arguments which are not just about mercy killing and crippling hospital bills but revolve around a regrettable decision she had made in the past. Mother, daughter and son have unsettled business, which nags not just the living but also the living-dead.

textlist.text: Connexion Point is a visual and interactive art piece generated from the patrons who come together to experience 2013's Nuit Blanche event in Toronto. Via a mobile web app and a multi-user, gesture-based, interactive interface, the stories and secrets of those who visit are collected, digitized, and projected into a colourful world of geometric, kinetic elements that evolve into a digital community over the course of the night.
This is just a sample of what is to come. A sneak peek into our process and a taste of what you can expect for our 'off-Nuit Blanche' installation.
Come and join us for a memorable experience on October 5th at Birch Contemporary Art Gallery
Starting at sundown.
Take part. Get connected.

textlist.text: This year we will celebrate Culture Days with an exhibition on “Identifying Inuit Art.” Bring your art objects to the museum and have them examined by a panel of Inuit art specialists. Or stop by and watch these detectives at work.

FREE with general admission.

entrydata.text: The DANCE THEATRE OF HARLEM’s unprecedented success is founded on creating innovative and bold new forms of classical ballet that reach new audiences while playing a key role in the national cultural dialogue. Founded in 1969 by Arthur Mitchell, the first African American dancer to become a principle dancer with a major U.S. ballet company (New York City Ballet), and the late Karel Shook, recognized as one of the most influential and productive ballet teachers of our time, the DANCE THEATRE OF HARLEM will present its eclectic repertoire at the Sony Centre For The Performing Arts with one performance on Saturday, February 8, 2014 at 8pm. Direct from the Victoria and Albert Museum, London and featuring more than 300 objects from Bowie’s personal archive, this multimedia show celebrates the artist’s collaborations in the fields of fashion, sound, theatre, art and film. An audio guide is part of the experience and is included with admission.

An interactive trip through Bowie’s legendary performances, highlighting his artistic influences and his experiments with Surrealism, German Expressionism, Music Hall, mime and Japanese Kabuki performance.

In addition to handwritten set lists, lyrics, diary entries, instruments and sketches, David Bowie is includes more than 50 stage costumes plus music videos, set designs, photographs and excerpts from films and live performances.

entrydata.text: David Holt & Lanny Shereck @ loop Gallery

textlist.text: In ILLUSTRATED HISTORY, Holt’s paintings continue to be inspired by museum displays, historical archives, catalogs, and encyclopedias, inviting multiple side by side visual comparisons within groups of art works, artifacts, archeological fragments, nature specimens, and other examples of natural and human history.

STUDIO VISITS is an ongoing series of large and small oil paintings representing artists at work in their studios. Engaging a longstanding tradition of painting artists at work, Shereck offers a voyeuristic glimpse of the aesthetic sensibilities of painters, sculptors, and writers as defined by their relationship to a personal creative space.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Day Job Doc - A Story of Chasing Dreams

textlist.text: Day Job Doc is a film that follows the gruelling process of three start-up companies in Toronto’s Extreme Startups Accelerator. The film explores the real life stories of these entrepreneurs as they build their idea into a startup company – each facing their own set of unique challenges over the intense 12-week program.

In the heart of Toronto where many start-ups are born, Jeremy Potvin, (CEO of Shifthub), Jayesh Parmar (CEO of Picatic), and Nima Garidideh (CTO of Venio) reveal their stories of hardships, sacrifice, and perseverance as they realize that chasing their dream requires a 24/7 commitment.

View trailer: www.youtube.com/watch?v=HDEe4WNppis
For more info and tickets, visit the Day Job website or call 416-572-2053.

textlist.text: Interior spaces reflect personality and lifestyle. When faced with making design decisions for the home, options can be overwhelming because numerous factors influence the choices made. With the goal of minimizing the guesswork, casalife and Catherine + Davis Interior Design invite you to discover your Design ID and see your personality come to life in a series of six vignettes showcasing six distinct personalities at Toronto’s Fall Home Show on October 3-6 at the Better Living Centre.

The original collaboration examines the aspirations of six unique design personalities, educating consumers on what motivates design choices through life’s different stages: First Timer, Modern Family, The Joneses, Bachelor, Modern Hippy and Baby Boomer.
As the air gets colder and the days get shorter, what better way to transition into fall than gain some instant good karma at a Charity Dishcrawl?
On Wednesday October 23rd, join us on this exploration of four of Toronto's enticing and enjoyable eateries in Baldwin Village!
For the first time in Toronto Dishcrawl History, we will not only be celebrating great food, fun and friends at 4 different restaurants, but also supporting our local communities.
Tickets are limited, so grab one, quick! and become a part of Charity Dishcrawl history!
Visit http://bit.ly/1eJ4FQT for details!

textlist.text: Eastern Breeze is an annual film festival held in Toronto, Canada, previews short and mid-length films of all genres including documentaries, animations, fiction and experimental from around the world which contains an eastern taste or philosophy. This is a public film festival that takes place every October in Toronto.

EBIFf aims to give new talents an opportunity to shine while, cinema fans can see the new films they would never be able to find in their local movie theaters. We are striving to expose and embrace the enigmatic eastern arts and cultures, by bridging and introducing the humanist, and soulful characteristics of these cultures in the modern west world, alongside celebrating Canada’s rich multicultural community.

entrydata.text: Explore Mesopotamia: Gold! Divine Light and Shine in Ancient Mesopotamia

textlist.text: History
Seminars/Workshops

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Texts speak eloquently about light and shine as positive aspects of works we call 'art' in Mesopotamia. The properties of gold in particular encode significant meaning -- especially when applied to headgear and personal ornament. This lecture will discuss the light-bearing properties of gold, its meaning when worn on the body, as well as the long-distance trade that brought this valued material into Ur and Nimrud, relevant to the present exhibition.
Bloor Street West and Queen's Park

entrydata.text: On October 9th, 2013 the Thompson Landry Gallery proudly welcomes back Yoakim Bélanger for his second solo exhibition, From Abstract to Abstract, a dramatic exploration of the human spirit on oxidized metallic surfaces. Through these 30 new paintings, Bélanger explores the limit between abstraction and reality in his expression of the human form. Not only do we see his figurative designs evolve, but it is the first time Bélanger will be exhibiting work that is abstracted in its entirety. Vital to Bélanger’s artistic process is his unique use of recycled materials, as these textured, metal surfaces act as a base to his vivid, layered brushwork.

entrydata.text: Get Inspired by the Main Stage at Toronto’s Fall Home Show

textlist.text: From home décor to renovation, local experts and celebrities will offer insight, inspiration and advice on all your home renovation and décor projects during Toronto’s Fall Home Show presented by Scotiabank.

Celebrity guest experts include Jonathan Scott and Drew Scott from W Network’s Property Brothers presented by Scotiabank as well as an exclusive Toronto appearance by paint legend Annie Sloan, creator of ChalkPaint™, who is one of world's most respected experts in the field of decorative painting and the author of 23 books on painting techniques. Other celebrity guests include Leigh-Ann Allaire Perrault (Cityline expert and Colour Aficionado), Vicky Sanderson (home product specialist) & Janice Fedak (Benjamin Moore Colour Expert).

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Jack Wilson (or Wovoka), a young Paiute man, had a vision during an eclipse of the sun in 1889, of a place where his ancestors were once again engaged in their favourite pastimes, where wild game and abundant food were restored to the lands. He interpreted the vision as the coming of a new age, one where Native and non-Native people would (finally) live in peace. This was the birth of the Ghost Dance. Curated by Steven Loft, this muti-media exhibition explores the role of the artist as activist, chronicler and provocateur in the ongoing struggle for Indigenous rights and self-empowerment. Artists: Vernon Ah Kee, Sonny Assu, Scott Benesiinaabandan, Dana Claxton, Cheryl L’Hirondelle, Alan Michelson, Theo Sims, Skawennati, Jackson 2bears.

textlist.text: The Evening will commence in the Library for a quick introduction and breakdown of haunted tales, a sneak peak at your hosts Paranormal Equipment, and perhaps listen to some of the amazing EVP’s captured during some of the investigations that have taken place at The Castle. We will then proceed forward for a mini tour – allowing you, our honoured guests, some extra time to investigate on your own!
For tickets, visit: http://canadasmosthauntedmedia.com/casa-loma

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Girls Learning Code: Learn programming with Ruby!

textlist.text: Family/Children
Seminars/Workshops

Ruby is an open-source coding language that allows us to speak to our computers through step-by-step instructions, and then be able to see (or hear!) the computer's response. Ruby can communicate anything from a simple mathematical equation to an interactive game, all through the use of Terminal - a command line interface. Girls Learning Code is excited to host this creative and diverse workshop for beginners, which will cover essential terms in the Ruby language such as: integers, strings, objects, all while focusing on how an everyday computer operates and understands input.
For more info and to register, please visit https://glcruby-september.eventbrite.ca/

textlist.text: In celebration of the Fall Home Show’s 25th anniversary and the 25th anniversary of Habitat for Humanity Toronto, 25 celebrity experts and emerging style, décor and DIY bloggers will source and repurpose 25 doors into functional upcycled items or hand painted pieces of art for the 2nd annual Upcycle Challenge: Unhinged at Toronto’s largest Fall Home Show presented by Scotiabanke. For more information or tickets visit www.fallhomeshow.com.

Confirmed participants include: Glen Peloso (celebrity designer) and Jamie Alexander (designer); Mag Ruffman (Tool Girl, TV host, producer, writer); Vicky Sanderson (home product specialist) with Jim Connelly; and Leigh- Ann Allaire Perrault (Cityline expert and Colour Aficionado) to name a few.

Celebrate the Fall Harvest season with Fresh City! Join us at Downsview Park on Sun, Oct 6th for an afternoon full of autumnal activities and homegrown goods. There will be local beer from Indie Alehouse Brewing Co., pumpkin pie from Cookie Martinez, fall soup from Urban Acorn Catering, savoury rolls from Nice Buns Bakery, vegetable pies from From Scratch Pie Co.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Haunted Toronto Halloween Scavenger Hunt for Adults

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
History
Bring a flashlight and a steady nerve as you uncover some of prim Toronto’s grisly past.

On an Urban Capers Scavenger Hunt, you don't collect items, but rather answers to tricky and humourous questions. Teams of two to six compete over the course of two hours. Indicate on the registration form whether you are signing up with a team or on your own and we'll set you up with a team.
Tickets must be purchased online in advance on our website.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Heritage Toronto Awards & William Kilbourn Memorial Lecture

textlist.text: Charity/Cause
Seminars/Workshops

This premier cultural event combines the annual William Kilbourn Memorial Lecture with an awards ceremony to celebrate outstanding contributions to the promotion and conservation of our city's heritage.

This year's Lecturer is Gail Dexter Lord, co-Founder and co-President of Lord Cultural Resources, a Toronto-based cultural planning firm which has advised governments, museums and other organizations around the world on innovative approaches to culture and heritage.

The Awards recognize individuals,community organizations, as well as industry professionals and associations, for exceptional contributions in five categories: Community Heritage, Media, Book, Short Publication and William Greer Architectural Conservation and Craftsmanship.

textlist.text: Tour Leader:
Philip van Wassenaer, Principal Consulting Arborist & Founder, Urban Forest Innovations Inc.

Join us as we explore the old, rare and otherwise significant trees around Queen’s Park and Philosopher’s Walk, located on University of Toronto campus. Some have as much heritage value as the historic buildings in the area. Expert arborist Philip van Wassenaer has worked locally, nationally and internationally on assignments concerning urban forestry and the preservation of significant trees for over 20 years. His passion for conserving heritage trees is contagious!
Eligible for up to 1.5 ISA CEUs.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: I Love Lucy® Live on Stage

textlist.text: I LOVE LUCY® LIVE ON STAGE is the brand-new hit stage show adapted from the most beloved program in television history! America’s favorite foursome – Lucy, Ricky, Fred and Ethel – is live on stage and in color for the very first time!

It’s 1952 and you are a member of the studio audience awaiting the filming of two hilarious and oh-so-familiar I LOVE LUCY® episodes. When the episodes begin and you witness, firsthand, the side-splitting antics of that crazy redhead in the Ricardo’s New York apartment and thrill to the Cuban sounds of “The Ricky Ricardo Orchestra” at the famed Tropicana Nightclub.
TV Guide’s William Keck calls it “the most entertaining stage production I’ve seen in years – including Broadway!”

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Seminars/Workshops

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: The Power Plant Contemporary Art Gallery

textlist.text: Juan A. Gaitán is curator of the 8th Berlin Biennale for Contemporary Art, 2014. Gaitán’s presentation will contextualize the recent history of the Berlin Biennale, its international relevance and comprehensive impact on the cultural life of Berlin, introducing his curatorial research and the artistic team he has invited for the 8th edition.
Read more at thepowerplant.org.

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: The Power Plant Contemporary Art Gallery

textlist.text: Julie Mehretu was born in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia and lives and works in New York City and Berlin. Mehretu is a recipient of many awards, and she has shown extensively in international and national exhibitions. Mehretu will discuss her recent body of work created in the aftermath of the Arab Spring, as well as her long-standing interest in psychogeographies as a major generating force in her drawing and larger conceptual projects as a painter.
Read more at thepowerplant.org.

textlist.text:
Salsa Dance Lesson at Atlantis Aquarius
This is an event for young professionals (25-40) brought to you by White Collar Socials. At this event we will be getting an hour long intro lesson to Salsa. This lesson will include the following - - how to find the beat and follow the dance rhythm in any Latin song - basic steps and footwork, partner work and coordination, turns and spins, styling - and a quick intro to more advanced level: dips, tricks and shines
Katia's approach is making sure you are having fun, feeling comfortable and getting confident for the dance floor!

Instructor Profile: Katia Tsvetkova
Katia has over 10 years of experience in Latin Dancing performing and dance instruction.

Highly regarded Toronto impressionistic painter and printmaker Jane Burns showcases her latest series ‘Enigma Paintings’. The solo exhibit begins Thursday, September 19 with a public opening reception (6:30-8:30 p.m.) and runs to October 12, 2013 at Leonardo Galleries, Yorkville. Note: Burns will also be present on Saturday, September 21, 2:00-4:00 p.m.
Exhibit link: http://www.leonardogalleries.com/index.php?p=exhibition&from=exhibitions&from_p=exhibition&s=69

Jane Burns, who was mentored by respected Canadian artists Hugh Mackenzie and Roly Fenwick, states, “Man’s relationship to nature is always important. We are part of it, and it is part of us. It is nature's mysteries that intrigue me in these works.”

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Jerash, Petra and the Mysterious Nabataeans

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
History
Seminars/Workshops

Examine the rise of Jordan’s indigenous Kingdom of Nabataea, the Hellenizing influence of its neighbours in the Decapolis, and its annexation as the Roman Province of Arabia in 106 CE. Considering the history, geography, archaeology and inscriptions of Jordan, evidence for “Romanization” will be contrasted with the resurgence of Arab power and identity in the fourth century CE. Particular attention will be given to comparing Jordan’s breathtaking archaeological sites of Jerash and Petra.
Instructor: Jonathan Ferguson is a teacher in the Education Department of the Royal Ontario Museum.

entrydata.text: With friendly and diverse vendors, weekly live music, programs for kids, and lots of neighborhood involvement, the John Street Farmers Market is a true community market in the heart of downtown Toronto. Whether you are on your way home from work, taking your dog for a walk, or exploring the city, our market is the perfect stop. Enjoy a coffee and a bite to eat in our beautiful courtyard cafe before heading up to the AGO's Wednesday free night, or grab a delicious, organic popsicle on a sunny day. We have hyper-local greens from Toronto backyards, organic produce from Prince Edward County, and lots of artisanal goods from a great variety of vendors. Natural and fun, ideal for a Wednesday afternoon.

entrydata.text: Kids Learning Code PA Day: Learn Visual Programming with Processing!

textlist.text: Please note: This workshop is for 8-13 year old girls and boys. Kids Learning Code is excited to host a full PA day of programming generative art with Processing! This workshop will focus on teaching the fundamentals of computer programming in a visual context, and highlight how simple mathematical equations can create beautiful and engaging outcomes. The Processing language builds upon the Java language, and is often used in electronic arts, new media art, and visual design.
For more info and to register, please visit https://klc-processing.eventbrite.ca/
Live performances
Theatre
art & lies productions presents: Killing Game - by Eugene Ionesco

Following the appearance of a mysterious “Black Monk” and the arrival of a devastating plague, a once gossipy burg quickly dissipates into packs of angry mobs, hypocrisy, crass opportunism, and arrant selfishness. Tragedy blends with the hilariously absurd, and clichés bend to controversy as we bear witness to the extremes these citizens will go to in order to ensure their survival. Only one thing is certain: there will be death.

entrydata.text: A FLAMBOYANT ENCOUNTER OF DANCE AND FINE ARTS, L’Atelier is a show for all audiences interested in the arts, 4 years old and up. Onstage, dance joyfully motions the audience through key trends in art history such as POLLOCK’S DRIPPINGS, EXPRESSIONISM, and POP ART. Each gesture describes a line, a spot, a shape or a color, and unexpectedly, a work of art is created before our very eyes.

The Canadian Opera Company opens its 2013/2014 season with the greatest love story ever sung, Giacomo Puccini’s La Bohème.

Canadian-born Tony Award-winning director John Caird, of Les Misérables and Nicholas Nickleby fame, premieres this new production of Puccini’s masterpiece of youthful flirtation, passionate love and heartbreaking tragedy, all set against the raucous streets of Paris’s Latin Quarter in the late 19th century.

With sets and costumes that capture the romance of France’s Belle Époque, this La Bohème features a young cast of opera’s hottest voices who bring the loves and lives of a group of young Bohemians to life in this beloved tale.

entrydata.text: Pianist and composer, Frank Horvat, will play piano for 20 hours in a row. His goal is to raise $10k for Lakeshore Arts. He'll keep playing if needed. Attend live or watch online via a live stream. Musical guests will join Frank at various times. You can also contribute to the music making by clapping along, chanting, bringing your own percussion instrument, or suggesting musical themes. The overnight hours will feature dimmed lighting and soothing sounds – bring your yoga mat! The piano-thon is being presented to recognize Lakeshore Arts’ 20th Anniversary. But equally as important, it’s raising funds to ensure that Lakeshore Arts can continue to deliver arts programming in South Etobicoke. Donate early & receive perks.

LE FA LE DO FOLLOWS ALBERT, AN ARCHIVIST NEARING RETIREMENT. As he sorts through recordings at the National Archives, he discovers a magnetic tape with the anonymous voice of a young woman singing Fado music. Mesmerized by her sensual and heart-rending voice, Albert is determined to locate the woman behind it.

He becomes unwillingly entangled in a wild cobweb of romantic setbacks, political conspiracies, State secrets, and occult groups. Torn between truth and absurdity, Albert will pursue his quest with the help of Jean-Daniel, the “urban cowboy.” Le Fa le do is a story of people who love and shun each other; an adventure combining the WILD WEST, SATIRE, POLITICAL THRILLER, and of course MUSIC.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Les Francophones pendant la Guerre de 1812

textlist.text: Bicentennial/War1812
History
Ils sont partout: dans les rangs, aux rames, aux canons, à la traque et à la frappe. Ils s’appellent Rolette, Baby, Rousseau, Mitchell, Laframboise, Garneau, de Salaberry ou de Boucherville…

Danièle Caloz, historienne et productrice de documentaires à Toronto, présente la Guerre de 1812 vue par le bout de la lunette francophone. Dans une causerie abondamment illustrée, elle raconte les péripéties vécues par ses héros à Michillimackinac, Détroit, Niagara, Toronto, Kingston et Châteauguay.

textlist.text: Cameron Mackintosh presents his acclaimed new production of Boublil & Schönberg's legendary musical, LES MISÉRABLES, with glorious new staging and dazzlingly reimagined scenery inspired by the paintings of Victor Hugo.
This new production has been acclaimed by critics, fans and new audiences and is breaking box office records wherever it goes.

The New York Times calls this production of LES MISÉRABLES “an unquestionably spectacular production from start to finish.” The London Times hails the new show “a five-star hit, astonishingly powerful.” The Star-Ledger says “a dynamically re-imagined hit.
Based on Victor Hugo’s classic novel, LES MISÉRABLES is an epic and uplifting story about the survival of the human spirit. Don't miss it!

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Life on the Grid: 100 years of street photography in Toronto

textlist.text: This free exhibit brings together photos documenting 100 years of life in Toronto, from the level of the street. Toronto landmarks like the St. Lawrence Market, Yonge Street and Kensington Market look at once recognizable, and yet totally different.

For this show we brought together photos from some of our most popular 20th century collections alongside new, rarely-seen collections. Just some of the things you'll see: TTC photos from the 1920's, Michel Lambeth's dark, poetic images of the St. Lawrence Market in the 1950's, and Ivaan Kotulsky's portraits of 'squeegee' kids at the intersection of Queen and Bathurst in the 1990's. A great show for anyone interested in the constantly evolving story of Toronto.

entrydata.text: Join Toronto’s movers and shakers, celebrity guests and awe inspiring artists as they come together on Thursday, October 10, 2013 to celebrate the gifts and achievements of recipients of the Schizophrenia Society of Ontario’s Scholarship Program - inspirational individuals whose lives have been profoundly altered by schizophrenia.Beneath the cathedral ceiling of the Berkeley Church on Queen Street East in downtown Toronto, revelers will enjoy an evening of artistry, excitement and togetherness, with tasteful tapas and entertainment including avant garde artistic performances, musical performances by Gruv Funktion and turntablists iNSiDEaMiND, a silent auction, and a Scholarship Live Auction.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Light My Fire: Some Propositions about Portraits and Photography

textlist.text: Light My Fire: Some Propositions about Portraits and Photography — a Primary Exhibition for the Scotiabank CONTACT Photography Festival in the context of its 2013 theme Field of Vision — celebrates the AGO's collection of more than 50,000 photographs, how it came into being and how it has evolved since 1977.

Presented as five propositions in two parts over the course of a year, the exhibition will celebrate the creative possibilities of portraiture in photography and feature more than 200 photographs from the collection, many shown for the first time.
The exhibition includes works by Richard Avedon, Julia Margaret Cameron,Liz Magor, Arnaud Maggs, Michael Mitchell, Irving Penn, Edward Steichen and Christopher Wahl, among others.

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society of Canada

textlist.text: The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society of Canada’s® Light The Night® Walk is the nation’s night to pay tribute and bring hope to all those affected by blood cancer. Each fall, teams of friends, families and coworkers gather in cities across North America to walk in twilight carrying illuminated lanterns: white for survivors, red for supporters; and gold for those walking in memory of someone.

Light The Night Walk events are evenings filled with inspiration. During this leisurely walk, thousands of walkers - men, women and children - form a community of caring, bringing light to the dark world of cancer.
Join us on Wednesday, Oct. 2, 2013 at David Pecaut Square and take steps towards a cure.

entrydata.text: Louisa May Alcott's classic novel about four sisters growing up in Civil War America is brought to life on the stage. Jo, an ambitious young girl, aspires to be a writer and finds inspiration in the memories of the lives, loves, and tragedies that she and her sisters experience coming of age while their father is off at war. For fans of the book or those experiencing the story for the first time, this show promises laughter, tears, and a lifting of the spirit.

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: LOST YEARS is an award winning documentary tracing four generations of racism as revealed through the journey and family story of Kenda Gee, a Chinese Canadian. Co-Produced/Directed by Kenda Gee & Tom Radford, the documentary begins in China in 1910 and concludes with the movement to embrace redress as a concept of social justice in Canada, the United States, New Zealand and Australia, exactly a century later.

entrydata.text: Mesopotamia showcases more than 170 priceless objects from the eminent collections of the British Museum. These artifacts, most never before seen in Canada, are augmented by those from the ROM’s own renowned collections and other leading institutions, including the University of Chicago Oriental Institute Museum, the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology (Penn Museum, Philadelphia), and the Detroit Institute of Arts. Presented in a series of well-defined themes, the exhibition features an outstanding selection of artifacts: stunning jewellery, dramatic stone sculptures, and impressive wall reliefs.

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: The Power Plant Contemporary Art Gallery

textlist.text: CURATED BY GAËTANE VERNA

The Power Plant presents a survey of significant work by Toronto-based artist Micah Lexier, bringing together a selection of recent work that reflects his diverse and dynamic practice. Whether working individually (One), in a collaborative process (Two), or encompassing more than one hundred different artists (More than Two), Lexier’s work evinces witty and playful reflections on the creative processes of making and presenting art. Read more at our website.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Murder at the ROM Halloween Scavenger Hunt For Adults

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
History

A curator has been murdered and a trail of clues left behind, connected to secrets in the collections. As you solve clues, you’ll begin to piece together a tale of greed, lust, pride and revenge. There are multiple suspects, one victim and you, the sleuths, must crack a cryptic code left in the curator’s appointment book to solve the mystery.

On an Urban Capers Scavenger Hunt, you don't collect items, but rather answers to tricky and humourous questions. Teams of two to six compete over the course of two hours. Indicate on the registration form whether you are signing up with a team or on your own and we'll set you up with a team.
Tickets must be purchased online in advance on our website.

textlist.text: The "Music & Truffles" series lets great youngsters hear great artists!

It's entertaining, it's interactive, and a wonderful opportunity to expose yourself and your children to classical music for a pittance!
Our season includes the Canadian Brass, the debuts of an acclaimed Spanish pianist and a European baroque band, a violinist and chamber ensemble.

The fourteenth annual NIGHT OF DREAD will parade our private and collective fears through the darkened streets of Toronto.
Join us for an evening of ceremonial festivities that allow us to call on, mock and banish the fears that unite and divide us in these times. All your fears are welcome to attend and be banished!

Come and dance in the streets with our city’s finest musicians, puppeteers, dancers and stilt walkers – Together we’ll laugh at our fears, waltz with death, eat the bread of the dead, and remember those who have gone from our midst.
Dress Code: Black & White & Dreadful
ALL ARE WELCOME.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Night of the Living Dead Live

textlist.text: Live performances
Theatre

Night of the Living Dead Live is a fun and hilarious stage adaptation of George A. Romero's legendary zombie movie. Set in 1968 and done in all black and white, it literally feels like the film has been brought to life and placed on stage. The play lovingly examines the film itself, the period it was made in and the film’s undying influence on the horror genre.

Night of The Living Dead Live is a theatrical tribute to all of the elements that make this cinematic masterpiece so endearing. More than just a recreation of the films story, the play celebrates the history and influence of the movie. Done through a series of multiple endings the characters are all faced with different issues and challenges as they try to survive the NIGHT!!!

entrydata.text: In the new Exhibition Common next to Ontario Square and Canada Square A breathtaking, large-scale outdoor photographic exploration of Toronto’s nine rivers. The exhibition features 80 large-scale photographic images creating the largest outdoor exhibition space in Canada. entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: No Dull Affairs: Karen Lofgren, Vanessa Maltese and Jillian McDonald

textlist.text:
Balls out confidence is needed to make art work an aesthetic event. In saying “balls out,” Curator Lisa Deanne Smith isn’t referring to a macho practice, but to the origin of “balls out” which refers to running a steam engine train at maximum speed via a governor or a speed limiter — when going full out without crashing, the balls rise to the top.
All of the work in No Dull Affairs references historical predecessors, seduces with craftsmanship and ultimately includes the viewer in its completion, creating a moment difficult to pin down with language without making it disappear — a balls out balancing act.
Presented with support from Glenfiddich Single Malt Scotch Whiskey.

We will showcase the Anti-Social collection until Oct 28, 2013.

Autumn is an exciting time for the city of Toronto, where creative energy is at a high point. Norman Felix Gallery welcomes Autumn with its annual show the Anti-Social. This year the group show features mixed media and painted works form 25 of our talented artists. The show highlights the eclectic mix of styles, techniques and visions unique to each of our artists.

textlist.text: Central West
Northwest

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: The Art of Life Community Health Center

textlist.text: “The Art of Life” launches 2 day seminar "The Art of Living the Healthy Life" with Jim Parry.

This is an enjoyable and introspective 2- day learning experience about how to live your dreams by planning for what you want, instead of settling for what you get. The core of the entire program is how to create a personal goal framework for achieving balance in your life in the following areas of health: Finances, Society, Family, Mental and Physical. You will also be provided with an effective 7- step success formula (it works!) for achieving your personal and/or business goals.

entrydata.text: Sheppard Avenue East and Dufferin Street

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Persuasive Psychology for Interactive Design (1-day crash course)

textlist.text: If you want to design digital technologies that are more engaging, but don’t have a lot of time to study persuasive design, then this one-day intensive crash course is for you.

During this one-day course, Brian Cugelman, PhD will cut to the chase, teaching you over 40 persuasive design principles and help you internalize them with clear visual examples, workbook exercises and group activities. You will learn how to critically assess the persuasive design features of websites, social media profiles, and mobile apps, showing you how to make your own technologies more engaging.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Persuasive Technology for Health Behaviour Change (2-day)

textlist.text: You may not know it, but online interventions can be twice as effective as traditional health behaviour change campaigns. This course will show you how these technologies work, and by the end of this course, you will understand how to build evidence-based health behaviour change interventions. This course is ideally suited to health communication specialists, social media community managers, health technology developers, and researchers.
Register now.

In the centenary of Benjamin Britten’s birth, the Canadian Opera Company presents his gripping opera about an alienated fisherman and the seaside village he struggles to inhabit, Peter Grimes.

World-renowned Canadian tenor Ben Heppner returns to the COC in one of his favourite and signature roles as the title character. Singing the role of Grimes’s unwavering advocate, Ellen Orford, is Ileana Montalbetti. Captain Balstrode, one of Grimes’s few friends, is sung by one of today's leading singing actors, bass-baritone Alan Held.
COC Music Director Johannes Debus conducts his first Peter Grimes, arguably the greatest opera of the 20th century, leading the COC Orchestra and Chorus through its evocative score.

Planet In Focus’ 14th annual Environmental Film Festival is being held November 21-24th 2013 at the TIFF Bell Lightbox and The Art Gallery of Ontario.

PIFF is Canada’s leading and most prestigious environmental film festival, with the 4 day event jam packed with an Opening Gala, guest speakers, award ceremonies, and film screenings. A wide array of film topics will be available for public viewing; anything from wildlife to political climates. In addition to screenings, the festival offers speaker panels, film production workshops, and educational school programs for both primary and secondary students. After every film, seminar, or series, there is a mass call-to-action to the audience to help change the world, one film at a time.

Pride and Prejudice is one of the most popular novels of all time, and no wonder: who doesn't long to be Lizzy or Darcy?

Now you can. Live the fantasy for one glorious afternoon, in a Regency-era gentleman's residence, wearing Regency clothes and speaking Jane Austen's words. No acting experience needed! If you need help with an outfit, let us know (well in advance, please!).

Any scene you like can be acted. Among the most fun are the proposals of marriage (Darcy to Lizzy x 2 and Mr Collins to Lizzy x 1, Charlotte Lucas x 1), but also electrifying is Lady Catherine's visit to Lizzy at Longbourne. Anything goes, any character you like!
Please note that pre-registration is required for both acting participants and spectators.

On September 29th we will host the Railpath Community Run on the West Toronto Railpath. All proceeds donated to The Stop Community Food Centre.
This is Toronto's only time-trial event where participants will loop the path as many times as they can in the 45-minute window allotted.
There are 2 participant waves. The 1st will be a runners’ wave geared and the 2nd will be a fun run/walk that will be more casual and have people of all abilities participating.

The event includes official chip timing every 1km on the course. Registration is $30/person via the Running Room (http://www.runningroom.ca) with special rates for groups and children. The fee includes a T-shirt, a shoe-tag-style finisher medal, refreshments and draw prizes.

textlist.text: Celebrations/Holiday
History

Swansea Town Hall commemorates the men of Swansea who gave their lives in World War I and for whom the Swansea Memorial Library was created. We also honour all those who served in wars and peacekeeping missions and those who have sacrificed themselves for Canada. The service will be held on the front piazza, weather permitting, or in the Rousseau Room on the main floor if it rains.
The ceremony will be followed by light refreshments and Remembrance Day Films to 12:00 noon in the Rousseau Room.
Everyone welcome.

This Dawn-to-Dusk fundraising event features hundreds of spirited road hockey games, as well as musical acts, celebrity appearances, interactive activities, food and beverages, and so much more! entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Robbing The Cradle of Civilization: Preserving the Art and Archaeology of Mesopotamia

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
History
Seminars/Workshops
While the human toll is the greatest consequence of war, this symposium looks at the other casualities of conflict; the damage and looting of archaeological sites and museums.

Using the looting of the Iraq Museum as a jumping off point, this symposium will look at recent history in Iraq, Syria, and other parts of what was ancient Mesopotamia, and try to understand what has happened and how we can protect the archaeological record in the future.

entrydata.text: Screening of Tunniit: Retracing the Lines of Inuit Tattoos

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Film

On Friday, October 11, 2013, the Museum of Inuit Art will be hosting a rare opportunity for visitors to view a screening of Tunniit: Retracing the Lines of Inuit Tattoos, a documentary on Inuit traditional face tattooing.

Following the screening, Alethea Arnaquq-Baril, the film's director, will speak about the film and her work as well answer questions from the audience.
This documentary is not yet available on DVD and has limited distribution, so this event presents a rare opportunity to see the film and hear from the director herself.
There will be limited seating so get your tickets today! Tickets can be purchased at the door or in advance at: miatunniitscreening.eventbrite.ca

At the moment there are no streetcars running to the Queens Quay Terminal from Union Station. Instead, take the 509 shuttle bus. Get off at York Street (the second stop). Head south across the street to the Queens Quay Terminal Building.
The Museum of Inuit Art is located in the Queen’s Quay Terminal Building at 207 Queen’s Quay West, Toronto. The Terminal Building is part of Toronto’s Harbourfront Centre.

The Museum can be found in the southwest corner of the Terminal Building. Our galleries overlook the shores of Lake Ontario. Access to the museum is through the Queen’s Quay Terminal Building. We do not have our own dedicated external entrance.

Each Tuesday night, Second City's greatest comedic minds throw away their scripts, and their inhibitions, to battle wits in a no-holds-barred frenzy of spontaneous hilarity. Best of all, the audience determines how the action will unfold, making each night a unique experience where anything might happen.

Improv All-Stars is a chance to see what has made Second City famous for more than 50 years, producing some of the world's most beloved comedians and inspiring hit shows such as Saturday Night Live, SCTV and Whose Line Is It Anyway.

textlist.text: Northeast
Northwest

The Reznicks are not your average immigrant family. Having arrived in L.A. in the mid 1950’s, Nathan and Sarah are a walking contradiction. Hallowed veterans of a right-wing Jewish underground in pre-independence Jerusalem, they are staunchly nationalistic, yet they live in L.A. far from their cherished homeland. Why? SEVEN DAYS follows the Reznick family in two parallel time periods separated by 15 years: the seven day mourning period following Sarah’s death in 1990, and the several weeks preceding their youngest son Barack’s abrupt departure in 1975.
World Première

textlist.text: A perfect pairing: Beer and the Bard! For two nights only this fall, The Classical Theatre Project (CTP) presents its Dora-nominated Twelfth Night while local breweries serve pints at the Covered Street of Artscape Wychwood Barns.

entrydata.text: Sherway Gardens' Gallery in the Garden: Toronto Back Lanes

textlist.text: Sherway Gardens’ current Gallery in the Garden exhibit entitled Toronto Back Lanes features acrylic paintings by Etobicoke artist Neil Whitworth. The exhibit is on display until October 12 in the corridor at door 3.
Capturing the quiet, personal spaces of the back lanes in the city, this series of paintings of Toronto’s Junction area by Neil Whitworth provide the viewer with an intimate look at everyday life.

Take a tour of the Junction through these paintings. Founded in 1884 as a village, the Junction grew into a town, and then it became the City of West Toronto. Today, much of the original architecture is still intact so you can experience the rich history first hand.

The market is outside from May to October and inside the Wabash Field House from November to April. During the outdoor season there are weekly children's activities as well as live music provided by the many talented musicians in the community. The Sorauren Market also hosts a number of community events throughout the year.

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: The Sorauren Farmers' Market has as it's mission to connect the public with those who produce their food. We have wonderful musicians who play for us every week creating a full and rich market experience.

textlist.text: Sorel Etrog is a career-spanning exhibition that will cast the artist in a new light in his adopted hometown of fift-four years. It will include his archetypal sculptures as well as drawings, paintings, book works and prints from the AGO's collection and private collections.

One of the highlights, and one of Etrog's pivotal works, will be his rarely seen film in collaboration with Marshall McLuhan, Spiral. This meditation on the human condition, from birth to death, will ba a catalyst for a renewed reflection on the accomplishments of one of Canada's most diverse and challenging artists.

entrydata.text: Sandra Rechico is a Toronto artist whose work often focuses on sites, routing and wayfaring. Her work has been exhibited across Canada and abroad. Her exhibitions have been featured in numerous publications and she has participated in international residencies in Australia, Germany and the Netherlands. She has also co-curated WADE, a city-wide art event in Toronto’s wading pools with Christie Pearson. She will speak on the exhibition Micah Lexier: One, and Two, and More Than Two.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: SYMPOSIUM / The Ecology of an Art Scene — Part I: Community: Un préambule

textlist.text: Arts/Exhibits
Seminars/Workshops

entrydata.name: PresentedByOrgName
entrydata.text: The Power Plant Contemporary Art Gallery

textlist.text: The Power Plant is pleased to host Community: Un préambule, part one of a two-part symposium, where chief innovators in contemporary art from Paris and Toronto will address the topic of community as it is taken up in contemporary art practices, institutions and critical discourse. Artists, curators, gallerists, museum workers, patrons, publishers and other cultural producers and community members will discuss what creates and sustains a vital art ecology.
Read more at thepowerplant.org.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: TAP Together Walks - New Toronto: A 19th Century Industrial Suburb

textlist.text: New Toronto was founded as an industrial suburb of Toronto in the 1890's. By the 1930s it had grown from a village to a town and became an industrial powerhouse. Hear about the growth of this community in South Etobicoke, as we view municipal buildings, an affordable housing project from 1918, the war memorial and other outstanding buildings. Heritage Toronto asks participants to consider paying what they can to help cover the costs, time and effort of staff volunteers.
Start Point: St. Margaret's Anglican Church, 156 Sixth Street (about one block NE of Lake Shore Boulevard West and Islington Avenue) Finish Point: Same as start point
Length: 2 Approx 2 hours

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Tarragon Theatre Season 2013: LOVE, LOSS, WINE AND THE GODS

textlist.text: Toronto, March 13, 2013 - Artistic Director Richard Rose and General Manager Gideon Arthurs are proud to announce Tarragon Theatre's 2013-14 season. Ten contemporary plays – which include world and English-language premieres.

Tarragon's sweeping new season journeys from the healing circles of British Columbia to the Bacchanalian rites of mythic Greece, from the romantic west coast of Ireland to a lonely tenement in Brooklyn, from the jolt of a mother's funeral to the dangers of sex tourism, from high society 19th century Russia to 21st century European corporate culture, and from a papal inquisition in 1606 Venice to a fast-forward lifetime of love in today's world.
The TBG Organic Farmers’ Market is in its third season! Come on out, rain or shine!
The market is located outdoors at the entrance to the Toronto Botanical Garden. Look for the grouping of white tents. Free parking is available on site.
Join us to meet organic farmers and buy local produce, bread, meat, cheese, honey, prepared food, and more! Come for your groceries, stay for dinner with your family.
Make your visit to the market an evening event at the TBG: FREE GARDEN TOURS AT 6 P.M. 10 FREE OUTDOOR CONCERTS AT 7 P.M. (JUNE 27 THROUGH AUG 29)

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: Part portrait of small-town Canada and part timeless fable, The Flood Thereafter is a magical play by Sarah Berthiaume, a rising star of Quebecois theatre. Every day, twenty-year-old June does an abrupt strip show in the gritty Emotions bar with all the men of the town watching and weeping. June’s relationship to the men stretches back to the sirens who ensnarled the mariners of ancient Greece, but when a young stranger arrives in town the tide begins to turn. Directed by Ker Wells.

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: The Great Upheaval: Modern Masterpieces from the Guggenheim Collection

textlist.text: This exhibition showcases the dynamism, creativity, and innovation of art produced in Europe in the years leading up to and during the First World War. A focus on the years 1910 to 1918 represents an intense chapter in European and world history, marked by sweeping social change, technological developments and scientific advances.

Featuring paintings from the collection of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum by artists Cezanne, Gauguin, Picasso, Kandinsky, Matisse, Modigliani, Duchamp, Miro, and Brancusi among others. The exhibition chronologically traces the achievements of these tumultuous years as artists experimented with new ways to create art while launching such movements as expressionism, futurism and cubism.

textlist.text: As one of the most special days of a couple’s life approaches, the Middle Eastern Bridal show was established to help men and women celebrate according to the customs of home…no matter how far home might happen to be.

Our goal is to bring all the Middle Eastern experience to our clients, right here in Toronto with all of the performances, foods, dress wear and culture you’d encounter at a traditional Middle Eastern wedding.
We have the joy of being situated in the most multicultural city in Canada, and this gives us even more pleasure to offer a unique blend of tastes, sights and sounds of the Middle-East.

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: The Stop's Farmers' Market, named Toronto's best Farmers' Market by NOW magazine, amazes every week with its array of tasty, seasonal Ontario food. The market supports local agriculture by encouraging our farmers to grow as sustainably as possible, and many of our farms are certified organic. All of our non-farmer vendors shop for their ingredients from the market. What you'll find year-round is honest, good food whose production causes as little environmental damage as possible and where everyone involved in its growing and distribution makes a living wage. There's also great music, community information booths, and lots of brilliant chefs making special treats every week.

entrydata.text: The Toronto Zombie Walk in support of The Heart and Stroke Foundation

textlist.text: The Zombie Walk started one gloomy Sunday, a week before hallows eve in 2003. A handful of the living dead rose from their graves to wander the streets of Toronto in search of brains.
The plague returned every year, and the zombie count grew into a large and deadicated legion of the undead. In 2012 we marked our tenth anniversary and we hoarded in over 9,000 people!

This year we are inviting ALL MONSTERS to participate in our PARADE! It will be the first parade in the world that allows everyone to participate! So if you’re a werewolf, a mummy, a vampire, a creature from the black lagoon, or a zombie (because come on, we all love to shuffle) come to Toronto’s first ever Zombie Walk and Halloween Parade!

entrydata.name: EventName
entrydata.text: Thunder in the Heavens: Mesopotamian Myth and its Ties to Western Religion

textlist.text: History
Seminars/Workshops

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text: The faith of the people who lived in the land between the two rivers was rich and diverse and influenced the faiths practiced by billions of people today. This course will take a look at the cosmology, deities and myths of Mesopotamia. Discussion will include: how the world was created(cosmology), who was divine (deities and celestial beings), what happens when the gods are angry (myths and legends) and how these tales/experiences are reflected in current belief systems.

Toronto After Dark Film Festival is one of the world’s leading showcases of thrilling genre cinema, screening new horror, sci-fi, action and cult movies over nine exciting October nights in the city, in the run up towards Halloween. Now in its 8th year, the festival has grown to become a signature event in Canada’s largest city, enjoying an annual attendance of over 10,000 enthusiastic film fans and over 100 members of press and industry.

textlist.text: Our season includes the Canadian Brass, the debuts of an acclaimed Spanish pianist and a European baroque band, a violinist and chamber ensemble and a joint performance by two prize-winning young Canadian string quartets. All and more are featured in the 25th season of Toronto’s Mooredale Concerts.

The October 6th program features quartets by Haydn and Tchaikovsky, and the Mendelssohn Octet in E flat, described by critic Conrad Wilson as “one of the miracles of nineteenth-century music.” Joining the Cecilia Quartet in the Octet is the Afiara String Quartet, second prize winner in the 2010 Banff Competition and a family favourite with Music & Truffles fans.

entrydata.name: LongDesc
entrydata.text:
Through richly painted cityscapes, Sears explores how car travel dictates our perspective of the landscape and provides us with fragmented memories of our environment. Windows distort our sight lines. Interior colors leak into the exterior scene. Light absorbs and spreads across scuffed-up glass, altering our view. Reflective surfaces such as mirror and metal bounce beams of light between each other, exaggerating the luminosity of outside light sources.
Presenting the view of Passenger, Sears constructs a movement-based experience within a static landscape, separated from sites by glass, rubber, and steel.

entrydata.text: Wood Utilization: The Maple Leaf Forever Tree Tour

textlist.text: Environmental
Walking/Hiking
Tour Leaders: Mark Phillips, Toronto Parks, Forestry & Recreation Councillor Mary-Margaret McMahon, Ward 32 Beaches – East York Michael Finkelstein, Eco-Woodturner

The magnificent maple tree which, in 1867, inspired Alexander Muir to write “The Maple Leaf Forever”, fell victim to an epic summer storm in July of this year. But did you know it will be getting a second life? Find out how the wood will be used to honor the cultural significance of this historic tree. Explore other trees in the neighbourhood and learn how you can salvage wood from your own trees to make beautiful furniture, bowls, and your own family heirlooms.
Eligible for up to 1.25 ISA CEUs
This tour is supported by the City of Toronto - Economic Development and Culture.

Anna-Louise will help record your memories of living in the community! What was it like when you moved in and what has changed? What are some of your favourite memories?
Participants are encouraged to bring old photographs. Spaces are limited. Please register. This special program is part of Culture Days 2013!
Register by calling 416-395-5720 or e-mail doprograms@torontopubliclibrary.ca Registration allows us to contact you if there are any program updates or cancellations.

entrydata.text: "Dowsing for Feng Shui and Space Clearing finding the living force"

textlist.text: In this presentation Susan will talk about Geoprosperous Places and balance many sources of Geopathic Stress including: Curry and Hartmann grids, underground water and minerals, vortex energy, earth faults, magnetic and gravitational anomalies, and excess Yin and Yang energy. We will review geomancy and earth acupuncture and other Feng Shui issues such as Ancestor influences, the I Ching and Bagua layouts.
This talk is based around Susan's New Book http://www.dowser.ca/ps.html Susan Collins | 905-833-2440 | http://www.dowser.ca/

textlist.text: This exhibit marks the 175th anniversary of the Rebellion by examining the personalities on both sides of the conflict: Sir Francis Bond Head's government, determined to preserve the status quo; William Lyon Mackenzie and the Reformers, equally determined to force change.
Over twenty years after the War of 1812 had ended, what defined a Canadian patriot? Was it unswerving loyalty to England - or striving for a more independent Canada?
Included with admission.

entrydata.text: “Let Me Breathe” – A Vegas Night Fundraiser for Pulmonary Hypertension

textlist.text: It’s Back! The Pulmonary Hypertension Association of Canada – Toronto Chapter is excited to present our 5th annual fundraising event: “Let Me Breathe” – A Vegas Night Fundraiser for Pulmonary Hypertension. With over 200 guests expected, the night will feature casino game favourites, live entertainment, live and silent auction, door prizes, raffles and much more!
If you are unable to attend but still like to support us, please consider to make a donation to PHA Canada through this link: http://bit.ly/letmebreathe2013
